member.name: T:BPUtil.Keystore
member.summary: Enumerates cryptographic keystores available in Windows.

member.name: F:BPUtil.Keystore.Machine
member.summary: The key is kept at the machine level so that all users can access it (in theory)

member.name: F:BPUtil.Keystore.User
member.summary: The key is kept at the user level so only the user who created the key can access it (in theory).

summary.para: Performs asymmetric encryption and decryption using RSACryptoServiceProvider and OAEP padding. This class is thread-safe.
This class can also be used to generate and export keys for later use.
Based on testing, the payload size limits are as follows:
* 1024-bit key: 86-byte payload limit
* 2048-bit key: 214-byte payload limit
* 3072-bit key: 342-byte payload limit
* 4096-bit key: 470-byte payload limit
This class can also be used to sign and verify using the same keys that are used for encryption and decryption.

member.name: F:BPUtil.AsymmetricEncryption.keySize
member.summary: RSA key size. Defaults to 4096. Key size mainly affects speed of key generation, and 4096 takes a couple seconds but is more secure than smaller key sizes.

member.name: M:BPUtil.AsymmetricEncryption.GenerateNewKeys(System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Generates new 4096-bit RSA keys without persisting them in the operating system's keystore.
member.param: CspBlob containing public key information, base64 encoded. Can be used for encrypting using .
The private (and public) components of the RSA key, base64 encoded. Can be used for encrypting using and decrypting using .

member.name: M:BPUtil.AsymmetricEncryption.GenerateNewKeysInKeystore(BPUtil.Keystore,System.String,System.String@)

summary.para: Generates new 4096-bit RSA keys, saving them in a key container in the operating system's keystore. Any existing key container with this name is deleted first.
The public key is exported via an out string parameter, but the private key information is not exported.
If you need to export the private key, you shouldn't bother using the operating system's keystore.

member.param: Specify which keystore the key should be saved in.
A string which uniquely identifies this encryption key among all other keys in the keystore. You'll use it again to access the encryption key later. E.g. "MyKeyForThisSpecificPurpose".
CspBlob containing public key information, base64 encoded. Can be used for encrypting using .

member.name: M:BPUtil.AsymmetricEncryption.GetKeyFromKeystore(BPUtil.Keystore,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns the RSA key from the specified key container. Behavior if the key does not already exist is configured via argument.
member.param: Specify which keystore the key should be loaded from.
A string which uniquely identifies this encryption key among all other keys in the keystore.
If true, the key is created if it does not exist (can fail and throw exception). If false, returns null if the key does not exist or is not accessible (not expected to throw).
If true, only the public key is returned. If false, the private key is returned.

member.name: T:BPUtil.BackupRotate
member.summary: Contains logic to decide, given a set of backup dates, which dates to keep and which to delete. The time between kept backups will increase exponentially. Ideal operation requires consistent backups (e.g. no missed intervals), but the algorithm can also do a decent job of handling the situation where expected backups were not created. Behavior is similar to the log2rotate algorithm, but the implementation is simpler.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BackupRotate.BackupInterval
member.summary: Defines the expected backup interval. The algorithm works best when backup dates are exactly this far apart, but it is not a strict requirement.

member.summary: Constructs a BackupRotate instance with the default backup interval of 1 day.

member.name: M:BPUtil.BackupRotate.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Constructs a BackupRotate instance with the specified backup interval.
member.param: Expected interval between backups. Default is 1 day.

member.summary: Returns an array of dates where the backups should be kept.
member.param: A collection of dates with backups available.

member.name: M:BPUtil.BackupRotate.DetermineBackupsToDelete(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.DateTime})
member.summary: Returns an array of dates where the backups should be deleted.
member.param: A collection of dates with backups available.

summary.para: Returns a modified base64-encoded string using characters which can be used in URLs without URL-encoding.
The output format is the same as standard Base64 except the characters '+' and '/' are respectively replaced with '-' and '_', while padding characters ('=') are simply removed from the end.

member.param: Data to encode.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Base64UrlMod.ToBase64UrlMod(System.String)

summary.para: Returns a modified base64-encoded string using characters which can be used in URLs without URL-encoding.
The output format is the same as standard Base64 except the characters '+' and '/' are respectively replaced with '-' and '_', while '=' padding characters ('=') are simply removed from the end.

member.param: Base64-encoded string

member.name: M:BPUtil.Base64UrlMod.FromBase64UrlMod(System.String)

summary.para: Decodes a string that was originally encoded via `ToBase64UrlMod`, returning a copy of the original byte array.
This method can also handle standard Base64 input strings, however with reduced efficiency.
This method can handle input strings which have had their trailing padding characters removed.
This method can handle input strings with certain unwanted punctuation or whitespace appended to the start or end.

member.param: A string that was originally encoded via `ToBase64UrlMod`.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Base64UrlMod.Base64UrlModToBase64(System.String)

summary.para: Decodes a string that was originally encoded via `ToBase64UrlMod`, returning a copy in regular Base64 format.
This method can also handle standard Base64 input strings, however with reduced efficiency.
This method can handle input strings which have had their trailing padding characters removed.
This method can handle input strings with certain unwanted punctuation or whitespace appended to the start or end.

member.param: A string that was originally encoded via `ToBase64UrlMod`.

You will be responsible for disposing the returned ImageFile.

member.returns: A thumbnail of the specified image.

member.name: T:BPUtil.NativeWin.Impersonator
member.summary:
FROM https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/10090/A-small-C-Class-for-impersonating-a-User
Impersonation of a user. Allows to execute code under another user context. Please note that the account that instantiates the Impersonator class needs to have the 'Act as part of operating system' privilege set.
member.remarks:
This class is based on the information in the Microsoft knowledge base article http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q306158
Encapsulate an instance into a using-directive like e.g.:
... using ( new Impersonator( "myUsername", "myDomainname", "myPassword" ) ) { ... [code that executes under the new context] ... } ...
Please contact the author Uwe Keim (mailto:uwe.keim@zeta-software.de) for questions regarding this class.

member.name: T:BPUtil.NativeWin.SingleInstance
member.summary: Enforces a single instance.
member.remarks:
This is where the magic happens. Start() tries to create a mutex. If it detects that another instance is already using the mutex, then it returns FALSE. Otherwise it returns TRUE. (Notice that a GUID is used for the mutex name, which is a little better than using the application name.) If another instance is detected, then you can use ShowFirstInstance() to show it (which will work as long as you override WndProc as shown above). ShowFirstInstance() broadcasts a message to all windows. The message is WM_SHOWFIRSTINSTANCE. (Notice that a GUID is used for WM_SHOWFIRSTINSTANCE. That allows you to reuse this code in multiple applications without getting strange results when you run them all at the same time.)
From http://www.codeproject.com/KB/cs/SingleInstanceAppMutex.aspx
Modified by bp2008

member.name: M:BPUtil.NativeWin.SingleInstance.Start
member.summary: Attempts to own a mutex that enforces that this process is the only running instance of this application. Returns true if successful, or false if another process owns the mutex. If Start returns true, be sure to call Stop before the application exits.

member.name: M:BPUtil.NativeWin.SingleInstance.ShowFirstInstance
member.summary: Shows the first running instance of the current application.

member.name: M:BPUtil.NativeWin.SingleInstance.Stop
member.summary: Releases the mutex that enforces that this process is the only running instance of this application.

member.name: M:BPUtil.NativeWin.NativeMethods.GetDIBits(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Byte[],BPUtil.NativeWin.NativeMethods.BITMAPINFO@,BPUtil.NativeWin.NativeMethods.DIB_Color_Mode)
member.summary: Retrieves the bits of the specified compatible bitmap and copies them into a buffer as a DIB using the specified format.
member.param: A handle to the device context.
A handle to the bitmap. This must be a compatible bitmap (DDB).
The first scan line to retrieve.
The number of scan lines to retrieve.
A pointer to a buffer to receive the bitmap data. If this parameter is , the function passes the dimensions and format of the bitmap to the structure pointed to by the parameter.
A pointer to a structure that specifies the desired format for the DIB data.
The format of the bmiColors member of the structure. It must be one of the following values.

member.name: M:BPUtil.NativeWin.NativeMethods.SetForegroundWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
Brings the thread that created the specified window into the foreground and activates the window. Keyboard input is directed to the window, and various visual cues are changed for the user. The system assigns a slightly higher priority to the thread that created the foreground window than it does to other threads.
See for https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms633539%28v=vs.85%29.aspx more information.
member.param:
C++ ( hWnd [in]. Type: HWND )
A handle to the window that should be activated and brought to the foreground.
member.returns: true or nonzero if the window was brought to the foreground, false or zero If the window was not brought to the foreground.
member.remarks:
The system restricts which processes can set the foreground window. A process can set the foreground window only if one of the following conditions is true:
Conditions
The process is the foreground process.
The process was started by the foreground process.
The process received the last input event.
There is no foreground process.
The process is being debugged.
The foreground process is not a Modern Application or the Start Screen.
The foreground is not locked (see LockSetForegroundWindow).
The foreground lock time-out has expired (see SPI_GETFOREGROUNDLOCKTIMEOUT in SystemParametersInfo).
No menus are active.
An application cannot force a window to the foreground while the user is working with another window. Instead, Windows flashes the taskbar button of the window to notify the user.
A process that can set the foreground window can enable another process to set the foreground window by calling the AllowSetForegroundWindow function. The process specified by dwProcessId loses the ability to set the foreground window the next time the user generates input, unless the input is directed at that process, or the next time a process calls AllowSetForegroundWindow, unless that process is specified.
The foreground process can disable calls to SetForegroundWindow by calling the LockSetForegroundWindow function.

Important Notes:

list.item: Returned sizes are approximate. .NET is a complex framework and I do not know all the intricacies.

member.summary: Gets the upper bound of the lifespan of a token. e.g. 20 minutes.

summary.para: A base class providing secure password reset functionality that requires no server-side state to be maintained between steps.

Accounts without an email address on file will be unable to use this password reset algorithm. Security is achieved by sending an email containing a link with a specially computed security token. The user making the request must click this link, thereby verifying to us that they own the email address which was on file for the account.
The security token is the cryptographic signature of the unique identifier for the account, combined with an imprecise timestamp (e.g. unix timestamp divided by 5 minutes).
Any server with a matching private key will be able to validate a security token within a short timeframe from its creation, and therefore allow the password to be reset.
After verifying account ownership, the user will be sent a new password.

member.name: T:BPUtil.Robust
member.summary: Provides methods to conveniently retry unreliable operations (typically file I/O).

member.name: M:BPUtil.Robust.Retry(System.Action,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Runs the specified action. If the action throws an exception, this method sleeps for a time and runs the action again. Sleep time is defined by the [delays] arguments, and the maximum number of retries is defined by the number of [delays] arguments.
member.param: Action to run.

param.name: delays
param.para: After failing to run an action, we sleep the thread for this many milliseconds. Each int from this array is used one time.

Example: Given a [delays] array of [5,10,20], the Retry method will wait 5ms after the first failure, 10ms after the second failure, 20ms after the third failure, and if the action fails a fourth time, the exception is simply rethrown.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Robust.RetryPeriodic(System.Action,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Runs the specified action. If the action throws an exception, this method sleeps for a time and runs the action again. Sleep time is defined by the [sleepTimeMs] argument, and the maximum number of retries is defined by the [maxRetries] argument.
member.param: Action to run.
Time in milliseconds to sleep after the action fails.
Maximum number of times to retry.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Robust.Retry(System.Action,System.Func{System.Boolean},System.Int32[])
member.summary: Runs the specified action. If the result is unacceptable or if the action throws an exception, this method sleeps for a time and runs the action again. Sleep time is defined by the [delays] arguments, and the maximum number of retries is defined by the number of [delays] arguments.
member.param: Action to run.
Function that should return true when the desired result is achieved. If this method returns false, the action may be run again.

param.name: delays
param.para: After failing to run an action, we sleep the thread for this many milliseconds. Each int from this array is used one time.

Example: Given a [delays] array of [5,10,20], the Retry method will wait 5ms after the first failure, 10ms after the second failure, 20ms after the third failure, and if the action fails a fourth time, the exception is simply rethrown.

member.name: T:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.TLS.Implementation.FragmentStream
member.summary: A read-only stream which provides to the reader a view of TLS fragment payloads. This class buffers one entire TLS fragment at a time (maximum size of one fragment is 16384 + 5 = 16389 bytes). Fragmentation is supported, however it is up to the caller to provide fragments and handle interleaving. The first fragment received locks this instance to accept only fragments of that type. If a fragment is provided that is not the same type as the first fragment, an exception is thrown.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.GlobalThrottledStream.ThrottlingManager.Initialize(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Calling this will enable web server bandwidth throttling and create the specified number of throttling rule sets and initialize them all to "unlimited" speed.
After calling this, you should modify each rule set via ThrottlingManager.BurstIntervalMs and ThrottlingManager.SetBytesPerSecond().
You should only call this function once; additional calls will do nothing.
Please note: throttling is incompatible with ASP.NET

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.GlobalThrottledStream.ThrottlingManager.SetBytesPerSecond(System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary:
Sets the bytes per second throttle for this rule. All streams using this rule share the same bandwidth pool that you set here. (can be set at any time, even while streams are active).
If less than 0, the value is clamped to 0. If 0, the streams using this rule will be unthrottled.

member.name: F:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.GlobalThrottledStream.IOOperation.leftOverFractionalBytes
member.summary: We can only transmit whole numbers of bytes, so this field stores the fractional remainder. This fractional part must be counted, or else data transmission will stop entirely if the allowed bytes per interval goes below 1.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.AddOrUpdateHeaderValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds or updates the header with the specified value. If the header already has a value in our map(s), a comma will be appended, then the new value will be appended.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.handleGETRequest
member.summary: Asks the HttpServer to handle this request as a GET request. If the HttpServer does not write a response code header, this will write a generic failure header.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.handlePOSTRequest
member.summary:
This post data processing just reads everything into a memory stream. This is fine for smallish things, but for large stuff we should really hand an input stream to the request processor. However, the input stream we hand to the user's code needs to see the "end of the stream" at this content length, because otherwise it won't know where the end is!
If the HttpServer does not write a response code header, this will write a generic failure header.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.CompressResponseIfCompatible
member.summary: Automatically compresses the response body using gzip encoding, if the client requested it. Must be called BEFORE writeSuccess(). Note that the Content-Length header, if provided, should be the COMPRESSED length, so you likely won't know what value to use. Omit the header instead. Returns true if the response will be compressed, and sets this.compressionType.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.EnableCompressionIfSet
member.summary: Called automatically by writeSuccess method; flushes the existing output streams and wraps them in a gzipstream if gzip compression is to be used.

member.name: P:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.ClientRequestsGZipCompression
member.summary: Returns true if the client has requested gzip compression.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.writeSuccess(System.String,System.Int64,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair{System.String,System.String}},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Writes the response headers for a successful response. Call this one time before writing your response, after you have determined that the request is valid.
member.param: The MIME type of your response.
(OPTIONAL) The length of your response, in bytes, if you know it.
(OPTIONAL) The response code and optional status string.
(OPTIONAL) Additional headers to include in the response.

(OPTIONAL) If true, sends the header "Connection: keep-alive" instead of "Connection: close". If you use keepAlive, you must either specify a contentLength (and honor it) or use chunked transfer encoding. If you specify keepAlive with a negative contentLength, the header "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" will automatically be added.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.writeFailure(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes a failure response header. Call this one time to return an error response.
member.param: (OPTIONAL) The http error code (including explanation entity). For example: "404 Not Found" where 404 is the error code and "Not Found" is the explanation.

(OPTIONAL) A description string to send after the headers as the response. This is typically shown to the remote user in his browser. If null, the code string is sent here. If "", no response body is sent by this function, and you may or may not want to write your own.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.writeRedirect(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a redirect header instructing the remote user's browser to load the URL you specify. Call this one time and do not write any other data to the response stream.
member.param: URL to redirect to.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.writeWebSocketUpgrade
member.summary: Writes response headers to finish the WebSocket handshake with the client. No extensions are supported (such as compression) at this time.

member.param: Data to send in the response. This string will be encoded as UTF8.
Content-Type header value. e.g. "text/html; charset=utf-8"
(OPTIONAL) The response code and optional status string.
(OPTIONAL) Additional headers to include in the response.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpProcessor.ProxyTo(System.String,System.Int32,System.Boolean,BPUtil.SimpleHttp.ProxyDataBuffer,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Acts as a proxy server, sending the request to a different URL. This method starts a new (and unpooled) thread to handle the response from the remote server. The "Host" header is rewritten (or added) and output as the first header.
member.param: The URL to proxy the original request to.
The send and receive timeout to set for both TcpClients, in milliseconds.
If true, certificate validation will be disabled for outgoing https connections.
If non-null, proxied communication will be copied into this object so you can snoop on it.
The value of the host header, also used in SSL authentication. If null or whitespace, it is set from the [newUrl] parameter.
If true, a Connection: close header will be added, and any existing Connection header will be dropped.

member.name: E:BPUtil.SimpleHttp.HttpServer.CertificateExpirationWarning
member.summary: Raised when an SSL connection is made using a certificate that will expire within the next 14 days. This event will not be raised more than once in a 60 minute period (assuming the same HttpServer instance is used). The TimeSpan argument indicates the time to expiration, which may be less than or equal to TimeSpan.Zero if the certificate is expired.

(Optional) Certificate to use for https connections. If null and an httpsPort was specified, a certificate is automatically created if necessary and loaded from "SimpleHttpServer-SslCert.pfx" in the same directory that the current executable is located in.
If not null, the server will bind to this address. Default: IPAddress.Any.

Thus, the set ["a50", "a3", "a400", "a s", "as", "as", null, null] would be sorted to:

member.name: M:BPUtil.CSVFile.StreamingRead(System.IO.StreamReader,System.Func{System.String[],System.Boolean})

summary.para: Reads CSV rows from the stream and allows them to be processed row by row without needing to load the entire stream into memory at once.
When each row is read, it is sent to [rowCallback].
If rowCallback returns true, the next row is read.
If rowCallback returns false, the function returns early.
Exceptions may be thrown if the CSV file is determined to be invalid.

member.param: A StreamReader positioned at the beginning of a line in a csv file.
A callback method which is called with the value of each row as it is read. If this function returns false, streaming of the CSV file will end immediately.

member.name: M:BPUtil.CSVFile.StreamingRead(System.IO.StreamReader)

summary.para: Reads CSV rows from the stream and allows them to be processed row by row without needing to load the entire stream into memory at once.
When each row is read, it is returned via yield return.
If rowCallback returns true, the next row is read.
If rowCallback returns false, the function returns early.
Exceptions may be thrown if the CSV file is determined to be invalid.

member.param: A StreamReader positioned at the beginning of a line in a csv file.

member.name: M:BPUtil.AppInit.WindowsService``1(BPUtil.WindowsServiceInitOptions)

summary.para: Call this from your Main() function, and it takes care of all initialization for a Windows Service app with the following features:

list.item: (Windows Only) Service Manager GUI with "Open Data Folder" button which opens in Explorer.
(Windows Only) A temporary instance of the service is automatically started if the debugger is attached.

If the service has a public static field named "settings" which inherits from SerializableObjectBase, that field will be instantiated if necessary, loaded, then saved if the settings file does not exist.

summary.para: Notice that some assumptions are made about the architecture of the application.
When running on linux, this class simply starts the service.
You may initialize with custom values, if desired, before calling this method.

member.param: Optional options for service initialization.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Globals.Initialize
member.summary: This method does nothing, but allows initialization to occur via the static constructor, where [exePath] is determined by , and WritableDirectoryBase is a subdirectory of . The directory pointed at by WritableDirectoryBase will not be created automatically, and the current working directory will not be changed.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Globals.Initialize(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Call this to initialize global static variables where the "WritableDirectoryBase" property is the parent folder of the exe.

param.name: exePath
param.para: Pass in the path to the exe in the root directory of the application. (if null/whitespace, then System.Windows.Forms.Application.ExecutablePath is used).
The directory must exist, but the exe name can just be a descriptive exe file name like "My Application.exe" and does not need to exist.
The exe name is used to create the CommonApplicationDataBase string.

member.param: A string to be appended to ApplicationDirectoryBase to form WritableDirectoryBase. Example: "" or "writable/" or "somedir/writable/"

member.name: M:BPUtil.Globals.InitializeProgram(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Call this to initialize global static variables where the "WritableDirectoryBase" path is a subfolder of .

param.name: exePath
param.para: Optionally pass in the path to the exe in the root directory of the application. (if null/whitespace, then System.Windows.Forms.Application.ExecutablePath is used).
The directory must exist, but the exe name can just be a descriptive exe file name like "My Application.exe" and does not need to exist.
The exe name is used in the error file name and exposed in and properties.

param.name: programName
param.para: A globally unique program name that does not change and is unlikely to collide with other programs on the user's system.
This defines the subfolder(s) of CommonApplicationData where this app's WritableDirectoryBase will be located.
So you could pass in "MyApp" or to be even safer, "MyCompany/MyApp".

member.param: If true, the directory defined by WritableDirectoryBase will be created if needed.

member.name: M:BPUtil.Globals.SetWritableDirectory(System.String)
member.summary: Call this after Globals initialization to change the writable directory path. The specified folder will be created if it does not already exist.
member.param: Absolute path for the writable directory. E.g. @"C:\MyApp\Data" or "/home/user/MyApp/Data"

member.name: T:BPUtil.ObjectPool`1
member.summary: A thread-safe pool where objects of a specific type can be stored and retrieved for later use. Pooling often-used or expensive-to-create objects can improve application performance at the cost of higher memory usage.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ObjectPool`1.#ctor(System.Func{`0},System.Int32,System.Action{`0},System.Action{`0})
member.summary: Creates an object pool.
member.param: A method which generates new objects of the desired type.
A limit for the pool capacity. Enforcement of this limit is not thread-synchronized, so it may be exceeded slightly if objects are put in the pool from multiple threads.

The ObjectPool will call this method for each object that is about to be added to the pool. Usually, it is fine to let this be null. If you are putting something like a List in the pool, you may want this method to call List.Clear().
When the pool is full, items that cannot be put into the pool will be passed to this action. If onDestroy is null, the item's Dispose method will be called if the type implements IDisposable.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ObjectPool`1.GetObject(System.Func{`0})
member.summary: Gets an object from the pool, or constructs a new one if none are available. You should assume all fields of the object contain garbage data.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ObjectPool`1.PutObject(`0)
member.summary: Returns an object to the pool so it may be obtained by a later call to GetObject(). Do not use the object after passing it to this method (let it go out of scope).
member.remarks: If the pool is currently at or above its max size, the item will not be pooled.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ObjectPool`1.NotAddingItem(`0)
member.summary: Called when the pool is asked to put this item in the pool, but the item is not being added because the pool is full.
member.param: Item that is not being pooled.

member.name: T:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags
member.summary: Flags which guide ProcessHelper.ExecuteInteractive in selecting a process to impersonate. The interaction of various flags is not well-documented, and study of the source code may be required to understand the resulting behavior.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateExplorer
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will prefer to impersonate explorer.exe. Since explorer.exe is not usually run as an administrator, it may be impossible to start a process that requires administrator.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateWinlogon
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will prefer to impersonate winlogon.exe. Rumor has it that a process impersonating winlogin is killed by the system after about 10 minutes.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateAnyProcess
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will fall back to impersonating any other process which does not have its own flag, but meets the other selection critera.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateLocalSystem
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will treat LocalSystem as a suitable user. When allowed by this flag, LocalSystem is the first priority.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateSpecificUser
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will treat a specific user (by name) as a suitable user.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateAnyUser
member.summary: If set, ProcessHelper will not care which user it impersonates.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteArgs.userName
member.summary: To be set when using ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateSpecificUser. This specifies the user name of the suitable user.

member.name: F:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteArgs.userNameIgnoreCase
member.summary: (Default: false) If true, case-insensitive comparison is used when matching the [userName] field.

summary.para: Specifies the session ID that needs to be impersonated.
If -1 (default), the argument will be replaced with the session ID of the active console (local monitor).
If null, any session ID will be acceptable to start the program in. Even session 0, which is where background services live!

member.name: M:BPUtil.ProcessExecuteArgs.#ctor(BPUtil.ProcessExecuteFlags,System.String)
member.param: Flags to guide ProcessHelper.ExecuteInteractive.
To be set when using ProcessExecuteFlags.ImpersonateSpecificUser. This specifies the user name of the suitable user.

member.name: T:BPUtil.ProcessHelper
member.summary: Provides Windows-only process utility methods.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ProcessHelper.ExecuteInteractive(System.String,System.String,System.String,BPUtil.ProcessExecuteArgs)
member.summary: Attempts to start the specified interactive process in the current console session (a.k.a. local desktop visible on the computer's monitor) by impersonating the security context of another process that is running in that session. This method can be called from a background service to start an interactive process. Returns the process ID of the executed program, or -1 if there was a problem. May also throw an exception.
member.param: This can be null if the first token in the [commandLine] argument is the executable path.

Sometimes, for unknown reasons, the first argument in this command line can be dropped. This may be avoided by passing null for [executablePath] and including the executable path as the first token of [commandLine].
Optional arguments to control process selection.
member.returns: The process ID of the executed program, or -1 if there was a problem. May also throw an exception.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ProcessHelper.GetConsoleSessionId
member.summary: Returns the current active console session Id, or -1 if there is no session currently attached to the physical console.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ProcessHelper.IsSuitableProcess(System.Diagnostics.Process,BPUtil.ProcessExecuteArgs)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified process is suitable for impersonation based on all the rules specified in the ProcessExecuteArgs instance.

member.name: M:BPUtil.ProcessHelper.ProcessOwnedByUser(System.Int32,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines if the specified process is owned by the specified user.
member.param: The ID of the process.
A user name. If the provided user name contains a domain name, the domain name of the processes's owner must match in order for this method to return true.
If true, the user name comparison is case-insensitive.

member.summary: Returns the name of the user which owns the specified process, including domain name. e.g. "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM"
member.param: The ID of the process.

Adapted from the "Tales from the CryptoRandom" article in MSDN Magazine (September 2007) but with explicit guarantee to be thread safe. Note that this implementation also includes an optional (enabled by default) random buffer which provides a significant speed boost as it greatly reduces the amount of calls into unmanaged land.

member.summary: Invokes on the GUI thread the specified action after the specified timeout.

(milliseconds) Values less than 0 are treated as 0. If the Timeout value is 0 for an OnGui operation, the invoke process will start before this method returns, making it impossible to cancel the operation.

member.summary: Gets or sets the soft maximum number of threads this pool should have active at any given time. It is possible for there to be temporarily more threads than this if certain race conditions are met. If reducing the value, it may take some time for the number of threads to fall, as no special effort is taken to reduce the live thread count quickly.

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum number of threads this pool should have active at any given time. If increasing the value, it may take some time for the number of threads to rise, as no special effort is taken to reach this number.

member.name: M:BPUtil.SimpleThreadPool.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Action{System.Exception,System.String})
member.summary: Creates a new SimpleThreadPool.
member.param: The name this pool shall have. Each thread created by this pool shall be named with this string followed by a space and an auto-incremented number.
The minimum number of threads that should be kept alive at all times.
The largest number of threads this pool should attempt to have alive at any given time. It is possible for there to be temporarily more threads than this if certain race conditions are met.
Threads with no work to do will automatically terminate after this many milliseconds (unless doing so would dishonor the [minThreads] limit).

If true, the application will be able to exit without waiting for all the threads in this thread pool to exit. Background threads do not prevent a process from terminating. Once all foreground threads belonging to a process have terminated, the common language runtime ends the process. Any remaining background threads are stopped and do not complete.
A method to use for logging exceptions. If null, SimpleHttpLogger.Log will be used.

member.summary: Prevents the creation of new threads and prevents new actions from being enqueued. Existing running actions remain running. This cannot be undone.

member.summary: Adds the specified action to the queue, to be called as soon as possible by a thread from the pool.
member.param: Action to run on the thread pool.

member.name: M:BPUtil.StringUtil.HtmlAttributeEncode(System.String)

summary.para: Encodes the characters '<', '>', '"', '&', and apostrophe as html entities so that the resulting string may be inserted into an html attribute.

remarks.para: Compared to HttpUtility.HtmlAttributeEncode, this method encodes the same characters plus the > character.
Also, until .NET 4.5, HttpUtility.HtmlAttributeEncode does not encode the apostrophe.

This method encodes the same characters as System.Security.SecurityElement.Escape(), with the difference being that the SecurityElement.Escape() method is intended for XML encoding and encodes apostrophe as ' while this method encodes apostrophe as ' which is more appropriate for HTML.

member.param: The string to encode.

member.summary:
Splits the input string into an ordered list of substrings that could be concatenated together to recreate the original input string. The produced strings will have a maximum length of [maxSegmentLength]. Instead of returning a list of strings, this method passes each substring into a callback method.
This method is designed to split a large text file into smaller chunks.
member.param: The string to split.
Maximum length of each substring. Minimum value is 1.
Try to end substrings early at characters ['\r', '\n', '.', '\t', ' '], to yield cleaner output.
A callback method that will receive each string that is split out of the original string.

member.name: M:BPUtil.StringUtil.ParseCommandLine(System.String)

summary.para: Given a terminal command, splits the command into its component substrings such that you could join them together again using a space as a separator to yield the original string.
For example, given this raw input:
"C:\Program Files\VideoLAN\VLC\vlc.exe" --rtsp-tcp "rtsp://127.0.0.1/"
... The method returns ...
["\"C:\\Program Files\\VideoLAN\\VLC\\vlc.exe\"", "--rtsp-tcp", "\"rtsp://127.0.0.1/\""]
... And calling string.Join(" ", ...) on the array above would yield the original input string.
Note that not all command strings may be entirely compatible with this method.

member.param: Command string that could be run in a text terminal.

member.name: M:BPUtil.WaitProgressivelyLonger.Reset
member.summary: Changes internal state back to what it was when this object was constructed.

member.name: T:BPUtil.BpWebResponse
member.summary: Contains HTTP response data. This is returned by methods in .

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.data
member.summary: The raw response payload as a byte array.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.headers
member.summary: A collection of http response headers. Keys are case sensitive.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.ContentType
member.summary: The value of the Content Type response header.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.StatusCode
member.summary: The HTTP status code of the response. 200 is normal success, 404 is Not Found, and so on. 0 indicates an exception was caught, and could indicate DNS resolution failure or connection failure.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse._str
member.summary: A cache for the string value of the response. This is populated the first time is requested.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.remoteIp
member.summary: The remote IP address of the server, in case a DNS hostname was used in the URL.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.ex
member.summary: If an exception was caught, it will be here.

member.name: F:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.canceled
member.summary: If the request/thread was aborted, this will be true.

member.name: P:BPUtil.BpWebResponse.str
member.summary: Returns the response in string format. The response is assumed to be UTF8-formatted string data.

member.name: T:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility
member.summary: Provides HTTP GET and POST methods which are useful in situations where the WebClient class falls short. An instance of this is intended to be used with only a single remote host. This class is thread-safe.

member.name: P:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.UserAgent
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the "User-Agent" HTTP header.

member.name: P:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.RequestTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the timespan to wait before the request times out.

summary.para: You can provide a proxy server here, if desired. Example: new WebProxy("127.0.0.1", 8888)
See , .
Also see .

member.name: P:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.UseProxy
member.summary: If false, no web proxy server will be used. If true, the will use the server. If Proxy is null, the will use automatic proxy settings.

member.name: P:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.BasicAuthCredentials
member.summary: If provided, all web requests will attempt basic authentication using these credentials.

member.name: P:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.AllowAutoRedirect
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the handler should follow redirection responses. The default value is true.

member.name: M:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a WebRequestUtility which can be used for multiple HTTP requests, even concurrent ones. This class is thread-safe.
member.param: User-Agent header value.
Initial request timeout in milliseconds. If 0 or less, this value is ignored. To modify after construction, see .

member.name: M:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.GET(System.String,System.String[],System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Performs an HTTP GET request.
member.param: The url to GET.

param.name: headers
param.para: An array of strings containing header names and values. The array should be populated in the order of "name", "value", "name", "value", and so on.
For example:
param.code: new string[] { "HeaderNameOne", "Header Value One!", "HeaderNameTwo", "Header Value Two!", "User-Agent", "Mozilla" }

member.param: (Advanced use) If specified, the connection will be dropped as soon as this many bytes are read, and this much data will be returned. If the full response is shorter than this, then the full response will be returned.
If specified, the response body will be streamed into this file and the response returned by this method will have a null data field. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.

member.name: M:BPUtil.WebRequestUtility.POST(System.String,System.Byte[],System.String,System.String[],System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Performs an HTTP POST request, sending the specified body content.
member.param: The url to POST.
The content to post.

If specified, the connection will be dropped as soon as this many bytes are read, and this much data will be returned. If the full response is shorter than this, then the full response will be returned.
The value of the content-type header to set.
Additional header keys and values to set in the request, provided as an array of strings ordered as [key, value, key, value] and so on. e.g.: { "User-Agent", "Mozilla", "Server", "MyServer" }
If specified, the response body will be streamed into this file and the response returned by this method will have a null data field. If the file already exists, it will be overwritten.
